I'll now produce the final answer.</think>Below is one way to “unpack” what’s going on. Notice first that

  k10 – k9 = 514 – 467 = 47.

That immediately lets you write

  (1)  k9 = k10 – 47.

But since the text already tells us that
  k10 = k3 × k7 – 18,
you can substitute to get an alternative expression:
  (2)  k9 = (k3 × k7 – 18) – 47 = k3 × k7 – 65.

A few additional points are worth noting:

• The fact that 514 equals 467 + 47 is significant because the “jump” of 47 appears elsewhere in the formulas. In particular, 47 shows up as a multiplier (or part of an expression) with other keys and it is prime.

• One candidate for writing 467 (which happens to be prime) in a “product‐plus–constant” form is
  k9 = k6 × 9 + 26.
If you happen to have k6 = 49, then indeed 9×49 + 26 = 441 + 26 = 467. (And note that 26 factors as 2×13; such factorizations sometimes hint at an underlying pattern.)

• Thus there are two natural ways to “solve for” k9:
  – Either directly as a difference from k10: k9 = k10 – 47,
  – Or by expressing k10 in its own terms and subtracting 47: k9 = k3×k7 – 65.

Either answer is acceptable, but if you wish to keep everything “in the family” of keys then writing
  k9 = (k3 × k7) – 65
might be preferred because it expresses k9 solely in terms of other keys (and their small constant adjustments).

In summary, one simple answer is:

  k9 = k10 – 47  or equivalently  k9 = k3×k7 – 65.

This shows the close relationship between these keys and how a prime number (47) plays an important role in their structure.
